page.title: 20Local history, Faceby (p.ii)
page.content: Of Whorlton's ruined motte and bailey {castle}only the 14th-century gatehouse bearing the arms of Meynell, Darcy and Grey, and vaulted cellars of an earlier date remain. The castle is privately owned and although made safe by the Department of the Environment, its isolated position encourages vandalism. A local group, "Friends of the Castle", periodically tidies up the gatehouse and surroundings. {Old Whorlton Church}stands in the parish burial ground which is still used. Only the chancel with a Norman arch, the columns of the south arcade dating from the 12th century and the north arcade into which was built the 14th-century tower still stand. Inside the chancel is the early 14th-century oak effigy of Sir Nicholas de Meynell, well preserved. {SWAINBY & POTTO WOMENS' INSTITUTE
